subject: Learning
title: Storage Strength vs Retrieval Strength
description: A quick, practical guide to Storage Strength vs Retrieval Strength.

hook.text: You can't recall your childhood friend's nameâ€”until you see their photo. The memory was there, just inaccessible.

buildup.text: Bjork proposed that memories have two strengths: storage (how well it's encoded) and retrieval (how easily accessed).

discovery.text: Storage strength never decreasesâ€”once learned, a memory is stored permanently. But retrieval strength fades fast.

twist.text: This means 'forgotten' memories aren't gone. They're stored but unreachable without the right cue.

climax.text: Spaced retrieval practice rebuilds retrieval strength each time, making memories increasingly accessible.

punchline.text: You haven't forgotten it. You've just lost the path. Practice rebuilds it.

quiz.question: According to Bjork, what happens to storage strength over time?
